channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Cease-Fire Will Begin Friday Morning, Qatar Says
item.description: The Qatari government, which has brokered talks between Israel and Hamas, said a pause in fighting would begin at 7 a.m. local time, with hostage and prisoner releases to follow. There was no immediate comment from Israel.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: India Faces Questions About Another Reported Foreign Assassination Plot
item.description: The U.S., while not publicly accusing New Delhi of trying to orchestrate a killing on American soil, said it had expressed concern to Indian officials.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and President Biden in Washington in June. News outlets reported on Wednesday that the Biden administration had told the Indian government it had information possibly linking New Delhi to an assassination plot.

item.title: Relatives of Those Stuck in Gaza Face Guilt and Fear
item.description: “When it comes to food, when it comes to freedom,” said one Washington resident whose brother is trapped in the besieged enclave, “the feeling of guilt is killing me.”
item.dc:creator: Rachel Abrams
item.media:description: Mohammed Salah Arafat looking out at the Capitol from the rooftop of his apartment complex. He is a Washington, D.C., resident whose family is still in Gaza.

item.title: East Africa Floods: Torrential Rain and Floods Wreak Havoc
item.description: The deluges have caused deaths and displacement in a region still reeling from its worst drought in four decades.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A woman trying to collect some belongings from her home in Garissa, Kenya, after flooding.

item.title: Finland Steps Up Border Closings in Dispute With Russia
item.description: The escalation comes as Finland tries to address a rise in the arrivals of migrants and asylum seekers that officials blame on Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Finnish border guards escorting migrants at the international crossing with Russia near Salla, Finland, on Thursday.

item.title: Far-Right Party Predicted to Win Dutch Elections in Landslide
item.description: The party of Geert Wilders, a longtime political provocateur with a history of antipathy toward immigrants and Islam, held a wide lead, according to early results, an outcome that could send shock waves through Europe.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Geert Wilders, the leader of the Party for Freedom, speaking after the first preliminary results of general elections on Wednesday in The Hague, Netherlands.

item.title: Putin Eyes Another Term as President, With War as Backdrop
item.description: There is little doubt about the outcome, should he run, but the election in March carries more significance as the first one since the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A photograph provided by the Russian state news media showing President Vladimir V. Putin at his inauguration ceremony in 2018.

item.title: U.K. Net Migration Numbers Hit a Record, Embarrassing Conservatives
item.description: The governing Conservative Party has long promised to reduce arrivals. It said Brexit would help. But the numbers in 2022 were the highest ever.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Even before the latest figures, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain had said that the immigration numbers were “too high, it’s as simple as that.”

item.title: Student’s Killing Pushes Italy to Confront Violence Against Women
item.description: The case of Giulia Cecchettin, found dead days before she would have graduated, has prompted an outpouring of rage and debate on how to shift an entrenched culture of chauvinism.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A vigil in Milan for Giulia Cecchettin, 22, who was missing for a week before her body was found in a ditch.

item.title: Olympic Truce for Paris 2024 Collides With Reality
item.description: Amid two prominent wars and other conflicts around the globe, a biennial call at the United Nations for peace during the Games felt even more symbolic than usual.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:description: The International Olympic Committee president, Thomas Bach, making the case at the United Nations on Tuesday for peace during the Games.

item.title: White House Eyes Possible Threat to Good Friday Agreement
item.description: Biden administration officials are watching whether the British government’s attempt to salvage its Rwanda asylum policy risks undermining the Northern Ireland peace accord.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Migrants are brought ashore after being picked up in the English Channel last week in Dover, England.

item.title: As Pakistan Expels Afghan Migrants, Families Are Ripped Apart
item.description: Husbands and wives, parents and children, wonder when, or if, they will ever see each other again.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:credit: Insiya Syed for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ram Bibi, the wife of Baz Gul, an Afghan migrant who was arrested and later deported from Pakistan.

item.title: A French Politician Refuses to Be Silent in the Face of Antisemitism
item.description: Yaël Braun-Pivet, a secular Jew, cherishes the French ideal of a national identity that subsumes ethnic division — and speaks out when her country falls short.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Yael Braun-Pivet, center front, the president of France’s National Assembly, leading a march against antisemitism in Paris, earlier this month.

item.title: South Korea Sentences Dissident Who Fled China on a Jet Ski
item.description: Kwon Pyong made the 200-mile journey in August in a bid for asylum. His worst nightmare was being sent back to China, a fellow activist said.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young

item.title: W.H.O. Asks China for Details on Surge of Respiratory Illness in Children
item.description: Reports of overcrowding at pediatric hospitals in China have raised concerns about a jump in respiratory illnesses affecting children.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Siyi Zhao
item.media:description: Children and their parents waiting at an outpatient area at a children hospital in Beijing on Thursday. The World Health Organization has asked China on Thursday for more data on a respiratory illness spreading in the north of the country, urging people to take steps to reduce the risk of infection.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: The intricacies of a hostage deal between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: An Israeli tank heads toward the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Israel-Hamas Pause in Fighting May Start Friday at Earliest
item.description: Both sides announced a four-day pause in the war between Israel and Hamas, but details were still being worked out.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Photographs of hostages in Ramat Gan, Israel, on Wednesday.

item.title: Cameron Ortis Found Guilty of Providing Secrets to Criminals
item.description: A jury convicted Cameron Ortis, who defended himself by arguing that he was engaged in a secret mission when he sought to sell secrets.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Cameron Ortis arriving at court this month in Ottawa. Prosecutors are seeking over 20 years in prison.

item.title: Deal to Free Child Hostages in Gaza Inspires Hope and Anguish
item.description: Some or all of the at least 36 children taken to the enclave as captives on Oct. 7 are expected to be freed. But the announcement raised anxieties about who might make it out.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protester at a march in Tel Aviv this month with a poster of Kfir Bibas, who has turned 10 months old while captive in Gaza.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Waiting for a Cease-Fire in Gaza
item.description: Plus Sam Altman is back at OpenAI.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Protesters rallied for the release of Palestinians being held in Israeli jails, and in support of Gaza, in Ramallah in the West Bank this month.

item.title: How the Israel-Hamas Hostage Deal Came Together
item.description: The agreement between Israel and Hamas required painful negotiations, but if carried out successfully, it could lead to the release of more hostages and extend the temporary cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display in Tel Aviv of photos of Israeli citizens held hostage in Gaza. The deal is set to free 50 of the roughly 240 hostages.

item.title: U.S. Presses Israel to Set Up Safe Areas During Coming Pause in Gaza War
item.description: President Biden and his aides are trying to get Israel to take measures that would reduce Palestinian civilian deaths and restore services.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. and international concern is growing about the civilian deaths and humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

item.title: For Israeli Officials, a Long, Hard Path to a Truce With Hamas
item.description: For weeks, senior Israeli leaders were divided about whether a temporary cease-fire might help Hamas regroup and endanger the remaining hostages.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley, Adam Sella and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Palestinians searching for bodies and survivors amid the rubble in the Jabaliya neighborhood after an airstrike in northern Gaza this month.

item.title: Joan Jara, Who Found Justice for Husband Slain After Coup, Dies at 96
item.description: She sought accountability in the military killing of the leftist folk singer Victor Jara in the right-wing turmoil that carried Gen. Augusto Pinochet to power in Chile in 1973.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Ms. Jara posed in 2009 in front of a photo of her husband, Victor Jara, a leftist Chilean folk singer and songwriter who was rounded up with others the day after a military coup in Chile and shot 40 times by troops.

item.title: Putin Bristles as G20 Leaders Criticize Aggression in Ukraine
item.description: For Mr. Putin, it was a rare interaction with Western leaders since the start of the war last year. It was also the first time he had to listen to direct public criticism at an international event.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin speaking via video conference at the G20 summit from Moscow, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: 1973: Israel Accepts Egypt’s Request on Small Issue
item.description: With the matter of the proper spelling of an Egyptian general’s surname settled, cease-fire talks proceeded.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Giving Thanks When the World Is on Fire
item.description: This year, I cannot count my blessings without also counting the sorrows and fears that lurk in their shadows.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub

item.title: In Gaza, Deal for Temporary Cease-Fire Brings ‘Little Bit of Relief’
item.description: Residents of the enclave expressed hope about a pause in Israel’s bombardment but felt that the agreement would not bring an end to the war.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Abu Bakr Bashir
item.media:description: Searching for casualties at the site of a strike on a house in Rafah, in southern Gaza, on Wednesday.

item.title: In Israel, Families of Hostages Held in Gaza Wait Anxiously for News
item.description: Hours after the cease-fire deal was announced, some relatives of hostages held in Gaza said they had received no official information from the Israeli authorities.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Family and friends of hostages at a news conference at Denmark’s Parliament in Copenhagen last month.

item.title: S​outh Korea Scraps No-Fly Zone Near Border With North Korea
item.description: A day after Pyongyang placed a military spy satellite into orbit for the first time, Seoul said it would no longer abide by a ban on surveillance flights.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A television in Seoul broadcast images on Thursday of Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, and others celebrating the satellite launch.

item.title: Ukraine Heads Into Winter With a Fragile Power Grid
item.description: Facilities remain hobbled by Russian attacks, repair work is unfinished and there is little spare equipment, although air defenses have been strengthened.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A power plant south of Kyiv last year. All of Ukraine’s nonnuclear power plants have been damaged by Russian strikes, the United Nations said.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A proposed cease-fire between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Faces of hostages projected on a wall in the Old City of Jerusalem this month.

item.title: Dutch Election: Unpredictable Vote May Elevate a Centrist
item.description: Unusually, a protest vote may be coalescing around a centrist, Pieter Omtzigt, as the Dutch vote in national elections on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.category: People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (Netherlands)
item.media:description: Pieter Omtzigt, at an event last week in Amersfoort, Netherlands, has offered voters a novel mix of left-leaning economic policies and right-leaning migration policies.

item.title: Israel and Hamas Agree to Framework of Hostage-Release Deal
item.description: The agreement calls for a pause in the fighting and for Hamas to free 50 of the captives it seized in its Oct. 7 raid on Israel. Hamas said Israel would release 150 Palestinians held in Israeli prisons.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Friends and relatives of people being held by Hamas took part in a “March for the Hostages” from Tel Aviv to the Israeli prime minister’s office in Jerusalem last week.

item.title: Families of Israeli Hostages Wait for Deal to Be Announced
item.description: Families don’t yet know if their loved ones will be returned when the planned cease-fire takes effect.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Eaton and Aaron Boxerman

item.title: Peter Tarnoff Dies at 86; Diplomat Helped Plot ‘Argo’ Escape From Iran
item.description: A consummate man behind the scenes, he held top posts under Carter and Clinton, and in between ran the Council on Foreign Relations.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Peter Tarnoff briefing White House reporters during the Clinton administration. He was part of a cohort of Foreign Service officers who, inspired by the words of President John F. Kennedy, joined the diplomatic corps in the early 1960s.

item.title: U.S. Conducts Airstrikes Against Iranian Proxies in Iraq
item.description: The airstrikes followed an earlier exchange in which a U.S. gunship spotted and fired on militants after they launched missiles at Al Asad Air Base.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: A Gaza Hostage Deal Appears Close
item.description: Plus Binance’s founder pleads guilty.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives of hostages taken by Hamas marching from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem last week.

item.title: Germany Freezes Government Spending as Budget Crisis Deepens
item.description: The government, scrambling to fill a budget gap in the wake of a court ruling, said it would halt future spending commitments.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, center, with Robert Habeck, left, the economy minister, and Christian Lindner, the finance minister.

item.title: At BRICS Summit, Countries Diverge Slightly on Israel and War in Gaza
item.description: They called for the release of all civilians who are being illegally held captive, as well as a humanitarian truce that would lead to a cessation of hostilities.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The leaders of BRICS nations, including President Xi Jinping of China, participated in a virtual summit on the war in Gaza.

item.title: Satellite Imagery Shows Ship Hijacked by Houthis Near Yemen Port
item.description: The vessel arrived Monday and was at anchor on Tuesday off the busy Red Sea port of Al-Hudaydah, according to an analysis of the imagery by The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and David Botti

item.title: Who Are the Palestinian Prisoners Who Could Be Released in the Hostage Deal?
item.description: Negotiations have centered on releasing women and children held in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Relatives and supporters of Palestinians held in Israeli prisons staged a sit-in in front of the Red Cross in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukraine Marks 10th Anniversary of Maidan Uprising That Foreshadowed War
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky hailed the so-called Maidan revolution, which toppled a pro-Russia leader 10 years ago, as the “first victory” in a long struggle against Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Placing flowers at a memorial in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, for those killed during the Maidan protests.

item.title: North Korea Launches Rocket With Its First Spy Satellite
item.description: The country had failed to put such a satellite into orbit in its two previous attempts at such a launch. This time, it was getting help from Russia, according to South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: People in Seoul watching a news broadcast about the launch.

item.title: Mosab Abu Toha, Noted Palestinian Poet, Disappears in Gaza, Family Says
item.description: Mosab Abu Toha was detained by Israeli troops as his family was evacuating to southern Gaza. A number of other Palestinians detained under similar circumstances remain in custody.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers detained blindfolded Palestinian men on Sunday near a road in the Gaza City area where other Palestinians were evacuating to the south.

item.title: 2 Journalists Killed in Israeli Strike in Lebanon, Network Says
item.description: The Lebanese military and Lebanon’s caretaker prime minister blamed Israel for the attack as the Israeli military said the episode was under review.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: Farah Omar, a reporter for Al-Mayadeen, a pan-Arab network.

item.title: Ailing Hamas Hostages Desperately Need Care, Doctors Say
item.description: Many of the more than 200 people seized by Hamas when it raided Israel had serious medical conditions. Some were badly injured in the attack. Doctors say they need medical care urgently.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: People gathered in Tel Aviv on Monday to demand the release of those taken hostage by Hamas on Oct. 7. Many hostages had medical issues before they were taken captive, are very young or were hurt in the attack.

item.title: What Are the Risks of A.I. Drones and Weapons?
item.description: Concern about weapons that can kill without a human decision is not entirely new.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: New technology from a company called ShieldAI creates drones that work in tandem through artificial intelligence. The company is working with the Defense Department, but does not have armed drones at this point.

item.title: A.I. Killer Drones Are Becoming Reality. Nations Disagree on Limits.
item.description: Worried about the risks of robot warfare, some countries want new legal constraints, but the U.S. and other major powers are resistant.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Edmund D. Fountain for The New York Times
item.media:description: An experimental unmanned aircraft at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida. The drone uses artificial intelligence and has the capability to carry weapons, although it has not yet been used in combat.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Conditions for women and children in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Thirty-one premature babies were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital and transferred to a hospital in Rafah in the south. Officials have said the babies will later be taken to Egypt for treatment.

item.title: Ukraine’s Children With Special Needs Suffer the ‘Huge Pressure’ of War
item.description: Children with conditions like ADHD and autism have been particularly affected by the traumas and uncertainties of the war and the disruptions to daily life, families and experts say.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: Electronic Warfare Confounds Civilian Pilots, Far From Any Battlefield
item.description: Planes were built to trust GPS signals. Jamming and spoofing in the Middle East and Ukraine have diverted flights and caused inaccurate onboard alerts.
item.dc:creator: Selam Gebrekidan
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Rishi Sunak’s Dilemma: When to Hold an Election He Looks Poised to Lose
item.description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is 20 percentage points behind in opinion polls. But history suggests the timing of a vote might make a difference.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, speaking at a college in London on Monday, must call a general election by January 2025.

item.title: Families of Hostages in Gaza Are Desperate for Proof of Life
item.description: Hamas has offered no information about the nearly 240 hostages, including children, who are said to be held in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members of hostages held in Gaza have been desperate for information at a moment when they have been receiving practically none.

item.title: Strike on Gaza’s Indonesian Hospital Kills at Least 12
item.description: The strike killed 12 people, officials said, at the Indonesian Hospital in the Gaza Strip, where the U.N. says most hospitals no longer function and those that do cannot provide complex care.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: A satellite image shows Indonesian Hospital, in Beit Lahia in the Gaza Strip, earlier this month, before Monday’s attack.

item.title: Video Shows Yemen’s Houthi Militia Hijacking Ship in the Red Sea
item.description: The video, released by the Houthi militia, holds clues about when and where the ship was hijacked.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and David Botti

item.title: Javier Milei’s Presidential Win Is Argentina’s Donald Trump Moment
item.description: Javier Milei has said that society is better without government. Now he is about to run Argentina’s.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Natalie Alcoba and Lucía Cholakian Herrera
item.media:description: President-elect Javier Milei greeting supporters on Sunday in Buenos Aires. “The changes that our country needs are drastic,” he said in his victory speech.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: OpenAI’s Future in Doubt
item.description: Plus India’s cricket heartbreak.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Sam Altman, the co-founder of OpenAI, left, with Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive in San Francisco this month.

item.title: Napoleon’s Hat Sells for $2.1 Million at Auction in France
item.description: The black bicorn hat, believed to have belonged to the 19th-century French emperor, had been expected to sell for far less.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: The hat is one of some 20 said to still exist of Napoleon’s two-cornered military dress hats that he wore as part of his everyday uniform.

item.title: Palestinian Mothers in Gaza Fear Giving Birth in a War Zone
item.description: The U.N. says that an estimated 50,000 pregnant women are caught up in the conflict in Gaza. Palestinian officials warn that the health care system has collapsed.
item.dc:creator: Neil Collier
